reviews.content: The Wizard of Oz is one of my all time favorite movies.  I have seen it many many times and, each time I see it I feel like it is the first time.  I am so excited they have brought it back to the big screen, so I to can have the chance to see the magic on the Big Screen.

reviews.review_title: A long review of The Wizard of Oz for my Film As Historical Literature Class, covering the story and it's symbolism.(SPOILERS INSIDE!)
reviews.content: The Wizard of Oz is a film best described as a metaphorical dream. It presents issues on two levels: those of a young girl, Dorothy Gale, a poor farm girl from Kansas who faces losing her dog to a nasty old woman, and those of a grander scale, like government evils and inefficiencies, and farming in arid Kansas. Under the guise of a children's book/movie, the story of The Wizard of Oz by L. Frank Baum is thought to be an allegory of the economic state of the Midwestern US and the Populist movement, of which Baum seemed to be a supporter, during the time that it was written. While the movie shows this, it was also changed to show more general ideals to reach a broader audience. Let us first look at the beginning of the film, and the characters. Starting on a dusty, windswept, desaturated Kansas farm, which seems to represent Dorothy's bland orphan life and presents the challenge that Dorothy is trapped in Boringsville unless she does something about it, the movie shows us the young, honest, pure, All-American girl Dorothy. Miss Gulch, a miserable crab of a woman, high up on the town's governmental ladder, is threatening canicide. Toto, Dorothy's dog and the only thing that brings joy to her otherwise black and white life, bit Miss Gulch, and now the old shrew is threatening Dorothy to take Toto away and have him killed. As Miss Gulch leaves with Toto, Toto escapes and finds his way back to Dorothy. The two then try to run away, but their plans are halted by a tornado. The next thing you know, Dorothy and Toto have just landed in Munchkin Land. Her house has landed on, and killed, The Wicked Witch of the East. The munchkins rejoice and Dorothy is rewarded with the witch's ruby slippers (which some believe represents "the 'inner spark' within all of us"), then sent on her way down the Yellow Brick Road to see the Wizard of Oz about getting back to Kansas. The Yellow Brick Road and the Ruby Slippers, which in the book are silver, are said to represent the gold and silver standards (monetary systems used during the 19th into the 20th centuries in which the paper bank notes were backed up by either gold or silver.). The main themes of the movie revolve around the idea of a better tomorrow, and there being "no place like home," and this Yellow Brick Road may also pose as a sort of "shining road to a better tomorrow/home." As the film progresses and Dorothy and Toto make their way down the Yellow Brick Road, they meet and befriend several characters. First to come along is the wise yet uneducated Scarecrow, representing the hard working hay-brained Kansas farmer who, despite his own view of himself, is smart, but lacks the education to prove it. Then comes the rust-frozen Tin Man, symbolic of the industry worker-compassionate, strong and sturdy but lacking a physical heart. Finally we meet the Cowardly Lion, king of the jungle, but afraid of everything. William Jennings Bryan, the thrice-defeated democratic presidential nominee who had many Populist views, such as bimetallism (having both gold and silver standards), is thought to be the model for the Lion. He was known as a great orator, but as they say, "his bark was greater than his bite," and Bryan had little power. Upon a more general view, the Lion may stand to represent the nobility of those who give up solely thinking about themselves and fight in defense of others and fight for what they know is right. The five go to Emerald City to ask the wizard for help, but they are sent away at first. Later the Wizard tries to intimidate them as they ask for their wishes to be granted. These scenes resemble the relationship between the higher government and citizens/lower government. The five are sent away at first because they could not possibly be important enough to speak to the Wizard of Oz, and when they finally do get to see Oz they come face to face with a giant, threatening, floating green head barking sternly at them. They only later discover, thanks to Toto, that Oz is just an insecure old man, with no real physical power, much like how government officials want us to think they are omnipotent deities. In one of the final scenes, the Witch is destroyed simply by being splashed with water. This is symbolic of the washing away of evil, but also, according to some sources, the Witch represents the dry Kansas soil. Her dousing can be seen as the taming of Kansas farmland. This point of view fits more with the book than the movie.The story of this film seems to be it's main driving force. It's direction, casting (with the exclusion of the always excellent Judy Garland), acting, and lighting are all average. It's cinematography and set designs are very interesting. The film almost looks more like a play than a movie, and it appears that this is because it was intended to have a storybook look to it. The music was timeless and extremely catchy. Everyone who has ever seen the film remembers the tunes. The only bad thing that can be said about the film is that it is not nearly as enjoyable since it has been analyzed to pieces and is no longer looked at as "just a movie."

This ambitious musical works on every level, despite the fact that it detours quite a bit from the original book from L. Frank Baum. The story, as everyone already knows, centers around young Dorothy (age indistinct in the film) and her search for "home." During her wild adventure, she survives being carried by a tornado and dumped into a surrealistic place called Munchkinland. Here she meets both the Wicked Witch of the West and Glinda, the Good Witch of the North. Glinda, already knowing how Dorothy can return to Kansas, sends her on an arduous journey down the Yellow Brick Road, where she meets the Scarecrow, Tin Man, and Lion. Throughout the film, each character clearly shows that he or she already possesses what they covet most, but the realization does not come until the end of the film.I have viewed this film at LEAST 50 times (I saw the original 1956 airing on CBS, and was there for the final showing this past May), and I'm STILL finding something new every time I see it. For instance, did anyone else ever notice that Toto has left some wet spots on Dorothy's dress in the very beginning of the movie when she leans down in the road? For me, however, the greatest joy comes from the wonderfully rich writing ("You clinking, clanking, colossal pile of coligenous junk!") Listen carefully at Miss Gulch's threat to the Gales at the beginning of the movie ("I'll bring a damn suit against your whole farm!") Please set me straight if I am  wrong. This film is timeless, if flawed by choppy editing at times. One of MY favorites, though!

reviews.review_title: The best movie of all time
reviews.content: This has to be the best movie of all time, it is such a classic, i remember watching this movie when I was a little girl and just loving every note that Judy Garland sang and I still feel the same. Just watching with amazement on the years that have past by that this movie has entered in so many lives. The memorable lines "there's no place like home." and my favorite "Well, I - I think that it - it wasn't enough to just want to see Uncle Henry and Auntie Em - and it's that - if I ever go looking for my heart's desire again, I won't look any further than my own back yard. Because if it isn't there, I never really lost it to begin with! Is that right?" I hope that if you have not seen this movie that you will cause it will forever have a special place in your heart.

One of the all time greats that never loses its appeal. The story of Dorothy Gale of Kansas and her spectacular trip to the land of Munchkins, good and bad witches, wizards, tin men, talking scarecrows and the cowardly lion is just as charming after the many times I have seen it as it was when I first saw it as a very small youth. One thing, no matter how many times you have seen this on TV, don't miss an opportunity to this classic on the big screen. You will be enthralled all over again.

This movie is awesome, It baffles me that this movie is even compared to Harry Potter which is complete Crap compared to this wonderful film. This movie truly is timeless, I'd wish every child in the world had the opportunity to see it.

reviews.review_title: The Best Movie of All Time
reviews.content: L. Frank Baum's beloved Classic the Wonderful Wizard of Oz is brought to life in this dazzling Musical! When 12year-old Dorothy is whisked away from her Kansas home by a Cyclone, she lands on the Wicked Witch of the East, in the Marvelous Land of Oz! Glinda, the Good Witch of the North gives her the magical Ruby Slippers & tells her that the only chance of getting home is to follow the Yellow Brick Road to the Emerald City to meet the Great & Powerful Wizard of Oz! Along the way she meets a Scarecrow who wants a brain, a Tin Man who longs for a heart, & a Cowardly Lion in desperate need of Courage! When they finally meet the great Oz, he tells  them they must kill the Witch of the West & bring him her broom-stick! see the movie to find out if Dorothy makes it home.This is a classic & fun for the whole family. Although it was filmed in 1939 & was one of the 1st films in Technicolor, it is timeless! With special effects which can still captivate the young mind. A must see for any fan of Fantasy & adventure!

The Wizard of Oz is the World's Greatest Film ever! It is casted greatly & the songs are wonderful! The sets are colorful & it is well directed. I suggest anyone who has not seen this film to get out of the whole they've been in the last 64 years & see it! The Warner Bros. DVD is a must have!

I remember The wizard of Oz rather disappointed and with some fright. The voice of the Wizard impressed me. I saw it as a ten year old or even younger, on a big screen theater. Spoiler. I was disappointed that the Wizard of Oz was a humbug. I think I had great hopes of watching a wizard doing marvelous things. Spoiler He does not help Dorothy. And he occupies the Title above the marquee. Watching Angela Lansbury on the 70 Anniversary Bluray, it was not surprise to me that she said that the film showed losings. Maybe not many kids could stand the above facts. Angela Lansbury also states that 85 million Americans go in 1939 to the movies every week, and that it was the 65 percent of the whole population, but this was not a favorite. Maybe the above statements were influential. regards

Simply one of the greatest films ever made. I've loved it ever since I was a child. How anyone could not rate this movie as perfect is beyond me. It represents a rare moment in motion picture history which will never again be repeated. They don't make films like this anymore.

reviews.review_title: The beginning of the tale movies.
reviews.content: At the first glance, I searched for the trailer of that movie, and to be honest I wasn't surprised or excited enough. Nevertheless, after familiarizing myself with it I found out that this movie is a piece of art, in short, because there are many compelling reasons to count it so. It is advanced both from the plot side and the filming technique side. I suppose that it is the first old movie in which I faced the early beginning of filming tricks and techniques. So it was wonderful to feel the energy that comes from the movie itself.As regards Dorothy's journey, it is really challenging to explain it, so that the audience could get the main point of the film, but I will do my best and keep my answer as short as possible. I think there is a number of ways to interpret the meaning of the whole story. One of the crucial ones is the actual lesson to the kids, as the story was made for a young audience. It instructs the children not to run away from their family and home despite any case, as it can lead to terrific outcomes in the end. Moreover, it assists to enhance the imagination of the younger generation who are only developing their thoughts and ideas about the world. Of course, it is a fairy-tale and it is dreamed up, but there is still something valuable to learn from, for example, we always search for the thing that we already possess or we should always be nice and friendly to each other. It may seem strange and so simple, but nowadays the humanity lacks things and characteristics exactly like this.Despite the short period of acting, Professor Marvel also plays a huge role in the particular story. I consider him as a wise old-man who gathers his grandchildren around himself and tells the amazing stories that the children will remember for their entire life, incredible, isn't it? In the Wizard of OZ, professor Marvel represents almost the same role if it is not bigger. However, his role is not explained enough I guess, because it will make a little bit difficult for children to figure out what is the main role of Professor Marvel.Last but not least, I fully agree with Dorothy at the end, "There is no place like home".)))

Calthough I get the feeling that everyone who wants to pick on the film or even openly hate it is doing so just to get attention for themselves. It's pure magic from start to finish. I could watch it a thousand times and experience pure, unadulterated joy every time. A cinematic classic, a Broadway musical brought to the big screen in color. Full of memorable songs and unforgettable scenes. The new 3D presentation brings the black and white scenes to life, while some of the color scenes, especially the wide shots, are too soft, but mostly everything is great.

reviews.review_title: So relevant to the current dystopia
reviews.content:
We've all been swept up by a tornado that has dropped us into a quest that we unconsciously initiated
by landing on the evil witch we carry within us, as well as the good. So of course, the magical slippers
go, not to the surviving witch, but to ourselves as we find our allies, the Tin man (love), the Scarecrow (wisdom)
and the Lion (power) in search of their manifestation and reclamation. And just as we have projected our safety into the Wizards outside of ourselves, like government and religion, they can only help by pointing to the fact that is we have always had the power to go home in the slippers of experience we wear and it is only by an act of compassion, Dorothy trying to put out the fire on the scarecrow and melting the witch instead, do we overcome
what we mistakenly believe imprisons us, just as we wake, like Dorothy, to find all the characters were just
impersonations of those who we find engaged with us in this life.

The Wizard of Oz is the best movie ever made. Well that's what I think. It's a family movie and the movie is very funny. This movie is a classic, because it's a original story. It's a movie about a little girl who wants to get away of the dark world. In a tornado she got sucked up and comes in a beautiful world.I think it have to be the number one of imdb, because it's funny and the actors are very good. They play with a lot of fun.

reviews.review_title: The movie to see in a theater
reviews.content: More years ago than I care to remember my mother took me to see this movie. This was when theaters were palaces. To a small boy the screen looked 50 feet high and 100 feet long. Sitting through the Movie Tone News I had no idea of what to expect. The curtains parted in the dark theater, and the movie started. When the movie started in what I thought was black and white, and I was disappointed. This was the age of color movies. But wait, the eyes of the actors had color. What was this? The actors had me. I didn't care if it was black and white. Dorothy sang the song that made history, and 'Some Where Over the Rainbow' captured the hearts of the nation. When Dorothy opened the door, after the tornado, I was trapped in the magic! The Color was like nothing I had ever seen before. Bille Burke looked like an angel in that bubble, and I hated Mararet Hamilton for 50 years. Ray Bolger, Jack Haley, and Burt Lahr showed that you could overcome your weakness. I saw 'Gone With The Wind' back then, and it was good, but not in my eyes. Buy the DVD, get the biggest T.V. you can find, get the heart of a 7 year old, and hit play. When you get to be my age you will find you yourself whistling 'If I only had a Brain', and find some 7 year old joining in. Sometimes you have to follow the yellow brick road, and not pay attention to the man behind the curtain, with your children. If you do, you will find Oz is not cable show about a prison, but a magical place you don't want to leave - even when your hair is gray, and all you teeth are not your own more than 50 years later.
This is based on all the political populist movement of the 1890's 19th century american prarie farmers and factory workers throgh through the writers experience.

This movie works on the multiple levels that great children's literature has. They're both there: the surface story of the girl that runs away from the bad place with her dog to find that beautiful land she's only dreamed of before, and the underlying theme of finding that she can go home and still have that dream in her heart.So is Oz a real place? It was certainly real to Dorothy. Maybe Kansas isn't real? Chinese philosopher Chuang Tzu dreamed a very vivid dream of being a butterfly. When he awoke, he asked, "Am I a man who dreams of being a butterfly, or a butterfly who dreams of being a man?" Maybe it was the same with Dorothy.See the special 50th anniversary edition if you can. It has some interesting extras, like the amusing deleted "Jitterbug" scene (which was included in a play I participated in in college).See it for Margaret Hamilton playing the Witch to the hilt. See it for the chance to remember Judy Garland as she was before her personal tragedies (seeing her sing "Over the Rainbow" on the Andy Williams Show was one of the most heart-wrenching experiences I have ever had, as her voice broke on "If happy little bluebirds fly above the rainbow-why, oh why can't I?"). See it for the discovery that "Oz never did give nothing' to the Tin Man that he didn't already have" (from "Tin Man" by America). See it just to have fun. But see it.

Everybody loves the Wizard of Oz, but for some reason the theater that was showing it in my area chose to show it in an anti-letter box format that would have fit just fine on my TV screen, but not on a movie screen.  I don't know if this is the case everywhere but it was a pretty big disappointment to go and see the Wizard of Oz on the big screen with black bars on the sides of the screen....
The Wizard of Oz is the greatest picture ever made!!  (I only registered to this IMDB thing just to say that)

If you watch the Wizard of Oz, you will be brought back to your childhood. You start to sing along with the Scarecrow, Tinman, Cowardly Lion, and Dorothy, and you don't even realize it. You pinch yourself wake up from the dream land you're in, but to a wonderful surprise, you find yourself awake.

This film was so cute. It is such a classic film in my opinion for children and adults. I don't know what makes it such a great film and makes it a classic. Its just so weird why we love it so much. I guess it brings your childhood to life. The wizard of oz is by far one of the best films ever.

Tonight I watched The Wizard of Oz the fifty-somethingith time during my fifty-somethingith years.  However, this is the first time I realized that this movie covered everything great and powerful in the film.  It had fantasy, mystery, horror, music and dancing, action, live animation, romance, morale, and special effects.  It showed rural life on the farm to big urban development such as in Emerald City or Munchkenland.  I was in awe and I always catch something I overlooked or under-appreciated in previous viewings.  I have seen this movie viewed through a young hippie-high-on-acid's eye but still enjoyed it as a clean-and-sober individual that I am today.  This movie is magical and realistic as it is classically contemporary.

reviews.review_title: THIS TRAUMATIZED ME AS A CHILD
reviews.content: I watched this aged 5 I think, the flying monkey things plagued my nightmares for weeks after I watched it. This movie would scare me even now if I watched it, especially now that I know all of the weird/terrifying things that went on behind the scenes!!! The only reason I didn't rate this 1 star is the fact that I am aware that it was filmed in the, like, 1930s so I guess there were different standards back then. Anyway in my opinion, this movie should stay back in the 1900s where it belongs. DON'T THOW RHIS TO ANYONE UNDER THE AGE OF 18.

This is my favorite movie of all time.  I would watch it over and over again when I was a kid.  I can not imagine a childhood without this movie. Yeah, the flying monkeys are a little frightening for some, but to me it is one of the greatest films ever made.

I certainly have enjoyed this movie for the fantasy it was for me over the years. Now, I see it completely differently. The Wizard is the Banker of London, the Rothchild family... Is there a difference ? The beast in the Bible given a real face ? I can see the banking system behind the curtain with all its magical treachery and deceptions. The paper money that has nothing to support it, no real value (as opposed to gold and silver), printed out of trees (money does grow from trees) and given a subjective value out of thin air (try to use Canadian dollars in the US). All other perspectives on the movie has been said. Maybe mine too. I just wanted to make sure it's there. Remember how fragile you can become. We are awakening.
I enjoy this movie, I love the songs and the characters.

reviews.review_title: I'm off to see The Wizard, until the day I die!
reviews.content: Simply one of the best Fantasy Films ever made. It never gets stale, no matter how many times you see it, or how old you get. One of Hollywood's Gem's.

This is one of the few all time classic movies.......FAR ahead of its time....the COLOR for a movie of 1939....is remarkable........This movie defies time and appeals to audiences of all ages...........Wonderful.....I can watch it over...and over.....with my children....and Grandchildren

reviews.review_title: I grew up on this movie!
reviews.content: I have always loved The Wizard of Oz since I was a kid and I still love it to this day.  I always watched it when it aired on CBS annually and I also have it on video.  I actually have 2 copies of the movie, the 50th anniversary tape and the Ultimate Oz package.After reading the script of the long version of the movie, I wish all of the outtake scenes were never taken out and destroyed.  If the movie actually ran too long, then I think the scenes could have at least been saved.  Then later on, they could have all been put back into their missing places.  Gone With the Wind was a 3-4 hour movie itself.  Why couldn't The Wizard of Oz be?  I guess there are many answers to that question.The one final scene that actually still does exist, is the scarecrow dance.  I think it is a little odd that every scene would be destroyed except for one. I'm sure there is an explanation for that too.  It's still enjoyable anyway though.  I have seen it probably 90 billion times and I'll probably see it 90 billion times more.  For any Wizard of Oz fan, I don't think 90 billion times would be enough.

This eternal gem of a film enters the digital revolution with ever-increasing appeal. Glowing healthier than ever before, this 1998 restoration seems to be the definitive version. The DVD format laps up the rainbow so wondrously that you might occasionally feel you're in Oz... As a perpetual lover of this film, I personally feel it has only improved with age. The original three-strip Technicolor hues of the DVD release are now vibrantly restored to their former lustre. One must praise the work of the restorers who seem to have obliterated any vestiges of artefacts or impurities from the Master print. Technicians have also color corrected former garish shades to subtle and more realistic variations. The film looks so breathtakingly sharp and clean that you might stop and wonder if it was filmed late last year. It would be safe to say that audiences of 1939 could not possibly have viewed the film with such articulate clarity and definition. Never have I been so taken aback while viewing Dorothy's entrance from bleak sepia tones to Oz's gorgeously rich colors. Other versions I have seen of this transforming scene do not convey the fluidity of movement and color shade that only DVD at its best can offer. The sharpness of the print allows us more than ever to become Dorothy's companions along her magical quest. Thanks to modern technology, our generation is allowed the privilege in seeing this classic as it so rightly deserves. This special DVD release also comes with many extra treasures. A behind-the-scenes documentary by Angela Lansbury journeys the film's making, while vintage movie clips, cartoons, outtake musical numbers, cast interviews and much more will keep many a buff awake. A must have for anyone interested in great classics. Take my word for it!

I saw this film like most people as a small child and was totally captivated by it.  From then on I must have watched the movie over 100 times and still it does not lose any of its appeal.  The costumes and sets are timeless as is the story, because afterall we all need a little fantasy in our lives. The clever combination of Sepia and Colour makes the colour scenes all the more magical.  If you haven't seen this movie on DVD I urge you to take a look. The film has been restored to its full glory and the features are as long as the movie itself. A great find for fanatics like me!!

This is truly the most wonderful movie that has been passed on to four generations of our family.  Our grand nephew and grand niece love to imitate the lollipop boys and the lullabye girls.  It is a joy to watch them watch a movie that is my all time favorite.

One of the most terrifying witches on the screen ! I was keeping Riccardo (my 4 y/o pearl) close to me when her green face appeared: no problem for him, he kept my hand to protect me ! What a fear 30 years later the first time !

reviews.review_title: Pink Floyds' soundtrack twist to The Wizard Of Oz
reviews.content: Get the film -> The Wizard Of Oz and Dark Side Of The Moon by Pink Floyd. Start playing Dark Side Of The Moon immediately after the MGM lion roars three times. Wish You Were Here is the second half of The Wizard Of Floyd soundtrack. When Dark Side Of The Moon ends down to the last very faint heartbeat (on screen you should see the Tin Man falling backwards & being caught by Dorothy and The Scarecrow)pause the film and put on Wish You Were Here... then unpause the film and start Wish You Were Here at the same time. I won't give away all the syncs in the film because they're fun to watch and listen to however you'll know you have the sync correct when during the little Moog solo at the end of the Wish You Were Here album as the witch is slowly melting the Moog solo is slowly fading out. When the witch has completely melted the Moog solo has completely faded out and the album ends there. For those of you who have trouble synching Dark Side Of The Moon you'll know you're in synch when after the warning bells (alarms)of the song "Time" ring warning that the mean lady is coming to Dorothys' home to take Toto away you'll notice that the alarms dwindle as she gets off her bike... and the key to the synch is 'at the same time as the fence door slams on her butt the first bass slap tones in the song "Time".' I did this with my friend over 6 years ago figuring that since Dark Side Of The Moon ends practically halfway through the film it is only logical that Pink Floyds' next album should cover the rest of the film and it does till Dorothys' mission is completed with the "hit" on the witch. "Money, It's a hit,Don't give me that do goody-good b.s." is sung precisely when the Good Witches' ball appears. The Good Witch appears all nice however she leads Dorothy to do a "hit" on the witch. When Dorothy finally does the "hit" on the witch that's where The Wizard Of Floyd ends.

a bet is on this one...I say it was shot in color, with the black and white scenes in the beginning and the end, like most sane people know to be true, but an acquaintance INSISTS it was shot entirely in black and white and later colorized. I know this cannot be true...,the B & W to color transition was a key element in creating the fantasy of a better life "over the rainbow"...(hello...rainbow...?). Besides, they didn't start colorizing movies until about the mid 80's. I grew up watching this movie, have been watching it my whole life, first saw it in the 60's and it is my all time favorite. Any info from anyone would be appreciated

reviews.review_title: I Love the Wizard of Oz!
reviews.content: I remember watching the Wizard of Oz as a child. It turned out to be my favorite movie of all time. I guess everyone wants to be Dorothy, and travel to a different place, and hope that your life could be different. I was also very afraid of the witch, but I loved the scare- crow, I think he was my favorite.  I have the movie and I watch it all the time. I never have tired of it, and now am passing it on to my grandchildren. Of all my childhood memories, waiting once a year for the Wizard of Oz to come on will be forever embedded in my memory. Remember after all, "There's no place like home".

reviews.review_title: Young Dorothy and her dog Toto are caught up in a cyclone and land in the fantasy land of Oz, and begin a quest to find the Wizard to help her return home safely.
reviews.content: I had met Margaret Hamilton and knew her fairly well. Once, when she was in my apartment in New York for dinner, she disclosed some trivia facts regarding her role in "The Wizard of Oz." For one, she said she was absolutely terrified of having to disappear in a sulfur-based cloud of smoke. With split-second timing she had to find a very small square in the floor of the set and stand on it as the smoke issued around her while she was quickly lowered out of the scene. She had a terrible fear of missing the square and falling into the area below. To make matters worse, several takes were required and she was greatly relieved when it was over. A most gracious lady, she loved to talk about the film.

I love this movie. I think that there is no movie before this or since this movie that can hold an audience young and old captivated. Everything about this movie is magical. The actors seem to be made for their part. The musical scores were wonderful and the theme was so simple and beautiful that anyone from all corners of the world can understand and identify with it. I've seen this movie many times over throughout the years and I'm 41 years old, and have watched it with my kids time and time again. A few years ago I took my wife to see this movie 'cause oddly enough she had never seen it and she too was captivated with it. I'll never tire of this movie and hope day to introduce my grandkids to it. So in my opinion this is the most magical and wonderful movie ever made.

I watched this movie twice , once in class once on acid , both expiriences were positive exept when on acid there was a lot of positive confusion added. It was a great laugh and visuals were fantastic (exept the flying evil monkeys). This is the kind of movie kids will love because of how cheerful it is and adults because of how half of the movie is just filled with repetitive dancing and stuff that wasnt important at all.

One thing people need to keep in mind when they see this movie... it was made in 1939! It's going on seventy years old. People seem to expect so much from this film. It's not going to have ground-breaking special effects (by today's standards), or amazing computer generated sets/landscapes, or superb make-up/creatures. It is a simple film with a beautiful moral and, honestly, what more do you need? Judy Garland shines as Dorothy, coming through as very natural and honest. You believe her, and you believe in her quest. And her voice... it is so filled with emotion! There is a reason why this film has remained so prominent in our culture. It obviously did something right. If not, its songs wouldn't be murmured on the lips the lips of young children to this day. We wouldn't be seeing Oz merchandise in Targets and Wal-Marts all across the US. It wouldn't have a set air-date on huge television networks every year for going on fifty years. It is the ultimate American classic.

In US History class, the most boring and particularly monotonous portion of the curriculum was the section spent on the incorrigible populists, who were clearly quote vexed about something in particular pertaining to the government, but I couldn't find anyone to explain it to me. The best reply that I got was: "Go watch the Wizard of Oz!" and then the door was slammed in my face as my high school librarian shut me out in a fit of pique. So I did, and I wound up more confused then I was in the first place. Finally, I received deliverance: the Wizard of Oz is a allegory for the populists, who wanted free coinage of silver so that they wouldn't have to be sent to debtor's prison. They, most farmers, are represented by the scarecrow; the tin man is for industrial workers, Toto represents abolitionists, while Dorothy herself symbolizes traditional American values. The reluctant hero of the populists, William Jennings Bryan, is portrayed by the cowardly lion; his nemesis, William Mckinely, is depicted by none other than the Wicked Witch of the West, who is, for some reason, greener than Kermit the Frog. While there are many other cross-references, including the "yellow brick road" (gold standard) and even the word "Oz" (as in ounces of gold), but I don't have the time or the patience to outline them all...

The movie shows two different settings: first was the Kansas setting with backdrop paintings of fields, hays, and lands. It shows a rural, pastoral, unsophisticated life in the farm. Second was the magical land of Oz.The backdrop paintings in the film made it look like a fairy tale movie. It has indeed appeared like a storybook with all other aspects working such as colors, costumes and props. It was like a fairytale that audiences of all ages had come to love.The costumes of the characters, from Dorothy down to the munchkins were all beautiful. Even the makeup of the characters was effective.Having also learned what the cast and crew had to go through in filming this movie, one can't help but admire the outcome of the movie. Their efforts were really worth it now that after 66 years, the movie is considered one of the greatest film ever made and the number one movie for families.Having learned that Judy Garland was 16 years old then and had to play 11 or 12 year old Dorothy Gale, it was not at all obvious that she was portraying a younger role. In fact, audiences would think that it would never be the same if someone else played the role.The movie has lots of dancing and singing, which is good since they kept the audiences' attention. Plus the songs are catchy, that after watching the movie you'll find yourself singing the songs.At the beginning of the movie, the color was sepia tone and actually not black and white. The sepia tone was used to emphasize the kind of atmosphere that Dorothy was living in, a dull, rustic, unsophisticated life at the farm.In the land of Oz, everything was colorful. One would think that he/she is watching an animated movie or a cartoon for that matter.The movie showed recurring shots of roads, both in Kansas and in Oz. They symbolized the journey that Dorothy would undertake in her transition from a child to a more mature person.The Wizard of Oz is a wonderful movie made beautifully and colorfully. At first I thought it was a children's flick but the way the narrative was carefully made got me enjoying the film. It got the kid in me singing, learning and understanding that I don't have to look far because the home is where the heart is.It is a kind of movie that would make you smile after watching it and you would think of the many times you wanted to get away (or even plan) from home. You would just sigh, because you know that Dorothy was right, indeed there's no place like home.

reviews.review_title: Wizzard of Oz is a thriller & classic!
reviews.content: I love the wizzard of oz it's a classic, fun, and great movie for all ages to enjoy! If anyone has not seen it I urge them to buy the updated version on DVD with behind the scenes and extra goodies for everyone to enjoy. Judy Garland was a wonderful actress, singer, and entertainer in all aspects of the entertainment industry. She was more than just another pretty face, or just an actress. She was a true entertainer in every aspect of the word. And continues to be an inspiration to many. The Wizzard of Oz is one of the world's most watched movies, and children of all ages and walks of life can enjoy the music, costumes, and comedy in this masterpiece. When it was released in 1939 the Wizzard of Oz was very cutting edge, and technologically advanced. I still enjoy watching it and if I ever do have children this will be a movie I will definitely pass on to them to savor! Thank you, R.I.P, Ms. Judy Garland! And remember pick up the DVD, you wont regret it!
